[[File:Photonic Propulsion First Lab Demo -YK Bae Corp.gif|thumb|528x528px|The [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TzLEK8Zq7Pk first photonic propulsion laboratory demonstration] by propelling a Cube Satellite spacecraft ([[CubeSat]]) with a photonic laser thruster (PLT) at Y.K. Bae Corp. In this demonstration, a 0.5 kW laser platform was used for PLT to deliver 3.3-mN photon thrust to a [[CubeSat]], which translates into a 500 kW intracavity laser beam.<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/323390665_Demonstration_of_a_mN-Class_Photonic_Laser_Thruster|title=Demonstration of a mN-Class Photonic Laser Thruster|last=Bae|first=Young|date=2016|website=ResearchGate|publisher=International High Power Laser Ablation and Directed Energy Conference|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-22}}</ref> The demonstration shows 1,000 times photon thrust amplification, and thus increasing photonic propulsion efficiency by 1,000 times. (3X Video Speed)]] [[File:PLT-Concept-Illustration.jpg|thumb|Figure 1: Anatomy of a photonic laser thruster, which was envisioned by Young Bae. The photonic laser thruster increases thrust by orders of magnitude by recirculating and amplifying photons between two mirrors that are located on the mother platform and the mission spacecraft. |328x328px]] [[File:PLT-LEO-Formation-Flying.jpg|thumb|Figure 2: The usage of Photonic Laser Thrusters is illustrated here for ultra-precision propellant-free formation flying of spacecraft to form an out-of-plane synthetic aperture on Low Earth Orbit.|324x324px]] A '''photonic laser thruster''' ('''PLT''') is an amplified photonic propulsion thruster for [[space propulsion]] that works on the principle of a photon-pushed sail, generating thrust directly from the [[momentum]] of a [[photon]] from a [[laser]] reflected from a mirror. The thruster, invented by Young K. Bae differs from other [[solar sail]] and [[laser propulsion]] thrusters in that an amplification process is used, in which the incident beam is re-used by being reflected by a stationary mirror, with an amplification stage at each reflection.<ref name=":17">{{Cite | url = http://arc.aiaa.org/doi/abs/10.2514/6.2007-6084 | title = Photon Tether Formation Flight (PTFF) for Distributed and Fractionated Space Architectures | last = Bae | first = Young | publisher = American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics |year = 2007 |journal = AIAA Space 2007 Conference & Exposition, Long Beach, CA | doi = 10.2514/6.2007-6084 }} Sept. 18-20, 2007.</ref><ref name=":14">{{Cite | url = http://arc.aiaa.org/doi/abs/10.2514/6.2007-6131 | title = Photonic Laser Propulsion (PLP): Photon Propulsion Using an Active Resonant Optical Cavity | last = Bae | first = Young | publisher = American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics |year = 2007 |journal = AIAA Space 2007 Conference & Exposition, Long Beach, CA | doi = 10.2514/6.2007-6131 }}Sept. 18-20, 2007.</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite | url = http://arc.aiaa.org/doi/abs/10.2514/6.2007-6156 | title = Photonic Laser Thruster (PLT): Experimental Prototype Development and Demonstration | last = Bae | first = Young | publisher = American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics | doi = 10.2514/6.2007-6156 |date = 2007 |journal = AIAA Space 2007 Conference & Exposition, Long Beach, CA | page = paper 2007-6156-318}}; Sept. 18-20, 2007.</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|url = |title = Photonic Laser Propulsion: Proof-of-Concept Demonstration|last = Bae|first = Y.K.|date = 2008|journal = AIAA Journal of Spacecraft and Rockets|accessdate = |doi = 10.2514/1.32284|pmid = |volume = 45|issue = 1|pages = 153–155|bibcode = 2008JSpRo..45..153B}}</ref> Because of the recycling of energy, the photonic laser thruster has been demonstrated to be more energy efficient than other laser-pushed sail concepts.
The near-term usage of the photonic laser thruster the earth-orbit applications include propellant-free and thrust-plume-contamination-free spacecraft maneuvering for precision [[Satellite formation flying|formation flying]], large optical and RF [[Synthetic-aperture radar|synthetic aperture]] construction, and [[stationkeeping]]. The usage of the photonic laser thruster for main space propulsion would require scaling-up of the laser power and controlling laser diffraction over interplanetary and interstellar distances. Photonic laser thrusters have a very high [[specific impulse]], and can permit spacecraft to reach much higher speeds that approach a fraction of the light speed, unlike conventional rockets, which are limited by the [[Tsiolkovsky rocket equation]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fiso.spiritastro.net/telecon/Bae_11-9-16/|title=Breaking the Tyranny of the Rocket Equation|last=Bae|first=Young|date=2016|website=Future In-Space Operations Telecon Presentation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-22}}</ref>
{{TOC limit|3}}
==History== ===Background=== The use of light for propulsion has been researched since the beginning of the 20th century,<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|title = From a Scientific Heritage|last = Tsander|first = Friedrich|date = 1967|journal = NASA Ttf-541|doi = |pmid = }}</ref> with the analysis of a sail pushed by the pressure of sunlight by [[Friedrich Zander|Friedrich Tsander]].<ref>Tsander, Friedrich (1925). "Problems of flight by jet propulsion: interplanetary flights"; in English translation as ''NASA Technical Translation F-147'' (1964)</ref> Photon propulsion has been discussed for decades as a propulsion that could enable interstellar flight.<ref name=":4">{{cite book|url={{google books |plainurl=y |id=GLWHQgAACAAJ}}|date=1 September 1995|isbn=978-0-07-031320-0|title = Space Propulsion Analysis and Design|last = Humble|first = R.W.|publisher = McGraw-Hill Co.|location= New York|pages = 631–683|last2 = Henry|first2 = G.N.|last3 = Larson|first6 = W.J.}}</ref><ref>G. A. Landis, “The Ultimate Exploration: Approaches to Interstellar Flight,” ''Interstellar Exploration'', Y. Kondo, ed., Apogee Books (2003).</ref>
In the traditional photonic propulsion, such as laser- or microwave-pushed [[Beam-powered propulsion#Direct impulse|lightsails]], photons transfer their momentum to the sail by reflection. Since, for a sail moving slowly with respect to the speed of light, very little of the energy of the photon is lost on reflection, a theoretical way to increase the efficiency is by recycling photons, bouncing the reflected photons back to the sail by a mirror,<ref name= "metzger" /> resulting in repetitively cycling the photons between two reflective mirrors in an [[optical cavity]].
The photonic thruster utilized this approach of recycling the reflected light, but with the addition of an active material amplifying the beam.
===Development=== The Photonic Laser Thruster (PLT) was invented and developed by Young Bae and his team at Y.K. Bae Corp for use in nanometer precision spacecraft formation under a [[NASA Institute for Advanced Concepts]] (NIAC) grant in 2006,<ref name=":18"/> for forming space telescopes and radars. Initial proposed uses include high-precision and high-speed maneuver of small spacecraft, such as formation flying, orbit adjustments, and drag compensation. In this research Bae discovered that photonic laser thruster was stable against movements of laser mirrors and proved that it can be used for main propulsion.<ref name=":5"/><ref name=":6"/><ref name=":14"/> In this program he demonstrated a 100-fold improvement in conversion efficiency, reaching a photon thrust of 35 micronewtons by putting the laser-energizing medium between two mirrors as in typical lasers.
In August 2015, under another NASA program (NIAC, NASA Innovative Advanced Concepts) he demonstrated additional 100-fold improvement, achieving a photon thrust of 3.5 millinewtons. In addition, a small 1U [[CubeSat]] satellite was propelled and stopped in simulated zero-gravity. The laser power of the trapped photon beam exceeded 500 kW, which was powered by a 500 W laser. The concept is proposed for beaming thrust from a conventional heavy "tanker" vehicle to a more expensive, lightweight mission vehicle, similar to [[aerial refueling]].<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|url = http://ykbcorp.com/downloads/DEMB.pdf|title = DE Momentum Beaming (DEMB) for Innovative Spacecraft Maneuvering|last = Bae|first = Y.K.|date = 2012|journal = DEPS Conference Proceedings|accessdate = |doi = |pmid = }}</ref><ref name=":0"/>
==Approaches==
===Beamed laser propulsion=== {{see also|Laser propulsion|Beam-powered propulsion}}
The limitations posed by the [[Tsiolkovsky rocket equation|rocket equation]] can be overcome, as long as the reaction mass is not carried by the spacecraft. In the Beamed Laser Propulsion (BLP) concept, the photons are beamed from the photon source to the spacecraft as coherent light. [[Robert L. Forward]] pioneered interstellar propulsion concepts including photon propulsion and [[antimatter rocket]] propulsion.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite journal | last = Forward | first = R.L. | date = 1987 | title = Advanced Space Propulsion Study | url = http://www.dtic.mil/dtic/tr/fulltext/u2/a189218.pdf | journal = AFRL Final Report | page = F04611–86–C–0039 | doi = | pmid = | accessdate = }}</ref> Specifically, Forward introduced beamed laser propulsion, aiming at the goal of achieving roundtrip manned [[interstellar travel]].
===Recycling photon propulsion=== Marx,<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Interstellar vehicle propelled by terrestrial laser beam|last = Marx|first = G.|date = 1966|journal = Nature|accessdate = |doi = 10.1038/211022a0|pmid = |volume = 211|issue = 5044|pages = 22–23|bibcode = 1966Natur.211...22M}}</ref> Redding<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Interstellar vehicle propelled by terrestrial laser beam|last = Redding|first = J.L.|date = 1967|journal = Nature|accessdate = |doi = 10.1038/213588a0|pmid = |volume = 213|issue = 5076|pages = 588–589|bibcode = 1967Natur.213..588R}}</ref> and Simmons and McInnes<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|url = |title = Was Marx right? Or how efficient are laser driven interstellar spacecraft?|last = Simmons|first = J.F.L.|date = 1993|journal = American Journal of Physics|accessdate = |doi = 10.1119/1.17291|pmid = |last2 = McInnes|first2 = C.R.|volume = 61|issue = 3|page = 205|bibcode = 1993AmJPh..61..205S}}</ref> calculated that the energy conversion efficiency of terrestrial laser-driven propulsion is approximately proportional to v/c at low speeds (v<0.1c), thus is small at low speeds (v<<0.1c). However, at higher speeds (v>0.1c), owing to the favorable [[Doppler effect|Doppler shift]] energy transfer, onboard photon propulsion becomes much more energy efficient.
[[File:Photon-Propulsion-Efficiency-Graph.jpg|thumb|Figure 3: Energy transfer efficiency from the photon energy to the spacecraft kinetic energy as a function of β=v/c.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}}|375x375px]]
Photons transfer their energy to the spacecraft by redshifting due to Doppler shift upon reflection, thus the higher the spacecraft speed, the higher the efficiency. The figure shows the energy transfer efficiency from photons to the spacecraft's [[kinetic energy]] as a function of β=v/c (the spacecraft velocity divided by the light velocity) in photon propulsion. As the spacecraft velocity approaches the light velocity (v≈c), the efficiency of photon propulsion approaches 100%, as if the spacecraft acts like a [[black hole]] in the moving direction.<ref name=":2" /> The lower solid curve in the figure represents the efficiency of conventional photon rocket or sail with photon recycling.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} The upper solid line represents schematically an example the efficiency of a recycling photon rocket, such as a PLT. At low β, the recycling rocket can have a high thrust amplification factor (in this example, ~3,000), however as β approaches 1, the amplification factor converges to 1 and the overhead of recycling is unneeded. Therefore, these rockets are projected to bridge the efficiency gap.[[File:Photon-Thrust-Amplification.jpg|thumb|Figure 4: Amplification of photon thrust by bouncing photon beams. As the number of bouncing and the distance between the mirrors increase, the beams start to overlap and the cavity changes from the Herriot cell to the Fabry-Perot resonator that is extremely unstable against the mirror movement.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}}|375x375px]] The simplest recycling scheme is a Herriot cell with multi-bouncing laser beams between two high reflectance mirrors that do not form a resonant optical cavity as illustrated in Figure 4. This cell type approach was first proposed by Meyer, et al.,<ref name=":12" /> followed by Simmons and McInnes.<ref name=":11" /> Mertzger and Landis<ref name= "metzger">{{Cite journal | last = Mertzger | first = R.A. | last2 = Landis | first2 = G. | date = 2001 | title = Multi-Bounce Laser-Based Sails | url = http://connection.ebscohost.com/c/articles/5662879/multi-bounce-laser-based-sails | journal = AIP Conference Proceedings | volume = 555 | page = 397 | doi = 10.1063/1.1357953 | accessdate = }}</ref> proposed a multi-bounce lightsail craft, such that the beam is reflected back and forth between the lightsail and a source reflector. Advanced reflectors permit more than 1000 bounces, reducing power requirements by 1000x compared to single bounce proposals. Using 100 MW to 1 GW lasers, a sub-100 day Mars transit is possible.<ref name= "metzger"/> The first experimental attempt on photon thrust amplification in a non-resonant Herriot-cell type optical cavity was performed by Gray et al.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Gray | first = P.A. | date = 2002 | title = Photon Flux Amplification for Enhancing Photonic Laser Propulsive Fo | url = https://ntrs.nasa.gov/search.jsp?R=20030005445 | journal = AIAA 33 Rd. Plasmadynamics and Lasers Conference Proceedings | doi = | pmid = | display-authors = etal | accessdate = }}</ref> who obtained amplified photon thrust of ~0.4 µN with a 300-W laser and a photon thrust amplification factor of ~2.6.<ref name=":14"/>
The passive resonator in the [[Fabry-Perot interferometer]] has been extensively used in high-sensitivity optical detection methods, such as the [[cavity ring down spectroscopy|cavity ring-down spectroscopy]]. One experiment produced 20,000 photon bounces using mirrors with 0.99995 reflectance.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = CW Cavity Ring Down Spectroscopy|last = Romanini|first = D.|display-authors = etal|date = 1997|journal = Chem. Phys. Lett.|accessdate = |doi = 10.1016/s0009-2614(96)01351-6|pmid = |volume = 264|issue = 3|pages = 316–322|bibcode = 1997CPL...264..316R}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Observation and Characterization of an Optical Spring|last = Sheard|first = B.S.|display-authors = etal|date = 2004|journal = Phys. Rev. A|accessdate = |doi = 10.1103/physreva.69.051801|pmid = |volume = 69|issue = 5|page = 051801(R)|bibcode = 2004PhRvA..69e1801S}}</ref> in which even one nanometer perturbation in cavity length destroys the resonance and nulls the photon thrust. The injection of laser power into the cavity remains challenging.
Meyer ''et al''.<ref name=":12" /> concluded that for interstellar flights, recycling photon propulsion vehicles are much more energy efficient than an onboard [[photon rocket]], such as the [[nuclear photonic rocket]]. They proposed possible applications of photon recycling using passive resonant optical cavities (lasers outside the optical cavity), such as the Laser Elevator.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal | last = Meyer | first = T.R. | date = 1985 | title = Rapid Delivery of Small Payloads to Mars | url = http://biblioteca.universia.net/html_bura/ficha/params/title/rapid-delivery-of-small-payloads-to-mars/id/43072158.html | journal = American Astronautical Society Science and Technology Series | volume = 62 | page = 419 | doi = | pmid = | display-authors = etal | accessdate = }}</ref>
==== Photonic laser thruster ==== After 2000 Bae began to investigate photon recycling for use in a nanometer accuracy formation flight, for a [[NASA]]-[[NASA Institute for Advanced Concepts|NIAC]] project called Photon Tether Formation Flight (PTFF).<ref name=":18">{{Cite journal | last = Bae | first = Young K. | date = 2006-01-20 | title = A Contamination‐Free Ultrahigh Precision Formation Flying Method for Micro‐, Nano‐, and Pico‐Satellites with Nanometer Accuracy | journal = AIP Conference Proceedings | volume = 813 | pages = 1213–1223 | doi = 10.1063/1.2169304 }}</ref> The goal was to sustain fixed-formation flight with a baseline distance between craft of over 10 km, for next generation NASA space missions. In 2006 Bae investigated active resonant optical cavities, in which the optical gain medium is located within the cavity, and coined the term "photonic laser thruster" (PLT) for such thrusters.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /><ref name=":14"/><ref name=":17"/> [[File:PLT-Mechanism-Diagram.jpg|thumb|Figure 5: Photonic Laser Thruster mechanism diagram shows its laser-like active resonance cavity with a laser gain medium in the cavity.|302x302px]]Initially PLT was proposed.<ref name=":18" /> It was assumed that the cavity would be sensitive to the stability of the mirrors and other optical parameters as in passive cavities. Bae discovered that he could sustain the resonance with the mirror in his hand.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /> This would be impossible if the cavity were highly sensitive to cavity perturbations such as moving and tilting. He concluded the gain medium in the cavity actively stabilizes the recycling photon beam, through negative feedback. This encouraged the idea that these thrusters could enable a range of applications well beyond PTFF.<ref name=":18" /><ref name=":6" />[[File:PLT-Demo-Setup.jpg|thumb|Figure 6: Schematic diagram of the first Photonic Laser Thruster (PLT) demonstration setup in December 2006.|298x298px]] In December 2006, a proof-of-concept of PTFF was demonstrated in a laboratory environment.<ref name=":18" /><ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /> Figure 6 illustrates the first demonstration setup, consisting of a concave High Reflectance (HR) mirror, a [[Nd:YAG laser|Nd:YAG]] Diode Pumped Solid State laser gain medium and a flat Output Coupler (OC) mirror. The photon thrust was determined by measuring the difference between the weight of the HR mirror with laser on and that with laser off with the use of a digital scale. Below is an infrared picture of the thruster in action. [[File:PLT-1st-Lab-Demo.jpg|thumb|An infrared picture of the first proof-of-principle demonstration of Photonic Laser Thruster, in which photon thrust was measure on a digital scale by measuring the mirror weight difference with power on and off.|250x250px]]
Figure 7 shows the experimental results of the photon thrust measured as a function of the laser power output through the OC mirror, P, with [[reflectance]] greater than 0.997 according to the manufacturer’s specification. Curve fitting the data resulted in the specific thrust of 20±1 µN/W, resulting in the apparent photon momentum multiplication factor of 2,990±150 and the true OC mirror reflectance used in this demonstration of 0.99967±0.00002. The maximum photon thrust demonstrated was 35 μN. When the demonstration setup was operating at thruster levels near or beyond 35 µN, the setup became unstable and the gain medium overheated. Therefore, it was realized that thermal management is critical to scaling such thrusters.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" />[[File:PLT-Thrust-Data.jpg|thumb|Figure 7: The first PLT demonstration data obtained with an output coupler mirror with 0.99967 reflectance.|265x265px]]
The Doppler shift limits the maximum obtainable velocity of the accelerating mirror and its accommodating spacecraft. Doppler shift effect on the active resonant cavity behavior is an extremely complicated issue.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /> Optical gain in the laser cavity can only occur for a finite range of optical frequencies. The gain bandwidth is approximately the width of this frequency range. For example, the gain bandwidth of the YAG laser system with the laser wavelength in the order of 1,000 nm is in the order of 0.6 nm,<ref name="Yariv1989">{{cite book|title=Quantum electronics|url={{google books |plainurl=y |id=UTWg1VIkNuMC}}|date=17 January 1989|isbn=978-0-471-60997-1|last = Yariv|first = A.|publisher = John Wiley & Sons}}</ref> ~ 0.06% of the wavelength. For an order of magnitude estimation, it can be assumed that a thruster utilizing the YAG laser system will be limited by the gain bandwidth to the first order, i.e., its theoretical maximum spacecraft velocity is ~{{val|1.8|e=5|u=m/s}} (180 km/s), 0.06% of the light velocity, c=3x10<sup>8</sup> m/s. To overcome this redshift limitation, at high operation velocities, wide bandwidth lasers should be used.<ref name=":2" />
Greater thrust requires higher power lasers.<ref name=":15">{{cite book|first1=Hagop |last1=Injeyan|first2=Gregory |last2=Goodno|title=High Power Laser Handbook|url={{google books |plainurl=y |id=0u0Foaw8wNYC}}|date=5 January 2011|publisher=McGraw Hill Professional|isbn=978-0-07-160902-9}}</ref> Lasers are often designed to maximize power outside the laser cavity, while PLT calls for maximizing laser power inside the cavity.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /> The necessary laser operation parameters to maximize intracavity power (circulating power) in laser cavities are still poorly understood.
[[File:PLT-TDL-System.jpg|thumb|Figure 8: TDL PLT |264x264px]] Bae and colleagues chose a thin [[disk laser]] and began to develop a PLT in 2013.<ref name=":15" /> Typically, a thin disk laser with a 0.2 mm disk thickness can be operated with a 99% output coupler, and provide an intracavity power 100 times larger than extracavity power.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Latham | first = William P. | last2 = Lobad | first2 = Ahmed | last3 = Newell | first3 = Tim C. | last4 = Stalnaker | first4 = Don | date = 2010-10-08 | title = 6.5 kW, Yb:YAG Ceramic Thin Disk Laser | journal = AIP Conference Proceedings | volume = 1278 | pages = 758–764 | doi = 10.1063/1.3507169 }}</ref> A schematic diagram of this design is shown in Figure 8. A thin disk gain medium is coated with HR with a reflectivity of up to 99.999% and attached to a heat sink. The recycling photons between the gain medium and the HR mirror located in the mission platform deliver amplified thrust beaming from the resource platform.
In 2014, Bae's group, working under a NASA program (NIAC, NASA Innovative Advanced Concepts), demonstrated intracavity power of 154 kW with a 0.6 cm diameter thin disk laser, which can be translated into a photon thrust of 1.03 mN.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.nasa.gov/spacetech/niac/2013phaseII_bae.html#.VGqrRvnF_SM|title = Propellantless Spacecraft Formation-Flying and Maneuvering with Photonic Laser Thruster|date = 2013|accessdate = |website = NASA Innovative Advanced Concepts (NIAC)|publisher = |last =Bae |first =Y.K. }}</ref> In April 2015, the group successfully [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QICCrlmBjvY&ab_channel=NASAVideo measured] photon thrust up to 1.1 mN with a digital scale. They were able to [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QICCrlmBjvY&ab_channel=NASAVideo accelerate], slow and stop a 0.45 kg spacecraft-simulating platform along a 2m frictionless air track in a Class-1,000 cleanroom. In August 2015, under the NASA program the group successfully [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TzLEK8Zq7Pk&ab_channel=Y.K.BaeCorporation propelled] a Cube satellite, and demonstrated and measured photon thrust up to 3.5 mN with the use of the newly developed NIST/Scientech/Navy radiation pressure sensor. An intracavity power of the photonic laser thruster over 500 kW was demonstrated with 500 W laser pumping.<ref name=":7" />
==== Open problems ==== To date the experimental tests of the photonic thruster are limited to laboratory-scale distances. The maximum range of operation for a photonic laser thruster, PLT, is yet to be established. Bohn<ref>{{Cite book | last = Bohn | first = Willy L. | date = 2008-01-01 | volume = 7005 | pages = 70051C–70051C–9 | doi = 10.1117/12.785634 | title = High-Power Laser Ablation VII | chapter = Novel aspects in laser propulsion }}</ref> demonstrated a 1 km-long laser resonator similar to the PLT cavity, which is an active cavity, in 1995 and proposed that such resonators could scale to 100 km. Recently, 4-km  [[Fabry–Pérot interferometer|Fabry–Pérot cavities]], which are passive cavities, but share the same intracavity power multiplication principle with the PLT cavity, have been demonstrated in [[LIGO]] for gravitational wave detection with an intracavity multiplication factor of 280 and an intracavity laser power on the order of 100 kW. Based on these results and the state-of-the-art technologies in precision optics, the PLT cavity length over 1,000 km is promising. Further studies need to be performed to determine whether the PLT cavity could be scaled for astronomical distances.<ref name=":2" />
Likewise, use of the amplifying cavity has not yet been demonstrated for the case when the sail is moving at velocities approaching fractions of the light velocity. The Doppler shift of the moving sail will, as noted earlier, mean that the amplification medium will need to operate at a different wavelength for each pass of the photons through the system. The mode of the Fabry-Perot cavity will likewise be changing with time.
Another issue is intracavity laser beam aiming, aligning and tracking over long distances.<ref name=":2" /> Progress in [[directed energy weapon]]s<nowiki/> has improved these capabilities. The speed of light limits how quickly tracking information can travel between the two cavity ends over long distances.
At speeds higher than rocket speeds lack of brakes is a problem.<ref>[http://livestream.com/viewnow/niac2015seattle/videos/105034354 Philip Lubin, Univ. of California Santa Barbara, DEEP IN Directed Propulsion for Interstellar Exploration, since 4:17]</ref> Such a problem can be solved by installing another photonic laser thruster at the destination as in photonic railway.<ref name=":2" /> The braking of spacecraft with PLT in lab has been recently demonstrated.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TzLEK8Zq7Pk</ref>{{better source needed|date=February 2018}}
== Applications ==
=== Orbit tuning === [[File:PLT-Synthetic-Aperture-Formation.jpg|thumb|Figure 9: Examples of satellite formation for forming synthetic apertures using PLT pushing-out force and counterbalancing "virtual tug" generated by differential gravity.|337x337px]] PLTs are studied for maneuvering spacecraft in near earth orbit, propellantless operation, thrust and power beaming for "perpetual" stationkeeping, and ultra-precision spacecraft formation flying, with or without tethers.<ref name=":18" /><ref name=":8" />
Norman and Peck analyzed<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":0">{{Cite book | last = Norman | first = Michael | last2 = Peck | first2 = Mason | publisher = American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics | doi = 10.2514/6.2009-6097 |title = AIAA Guidance, Navigation, and Control Conference|year = 2009|isbn = 978-1-60086-978-5}}</ref> a group of spacecraft that can exploit relative positions and velocities so that differential gravity provides a force opposite to the photon thrust from a PLT. In such a scheme, with two orbiting platforms moving in formation, when the photon thrust changes, their positions relative to the center of mass change as well, until the "virtual gravitational tug" counterbalances it again.<ref name=":17"/><ref name=":0" /> Existing concepts with conventional thrusters are not persistent, are mechanically constrained (e.g. with tethers), or lie within the orbital plane, limiting their aperture for earth-observation missions.<ref name=":0" /> This system in contrast could control of out-of-plane motions. Figure 9 shows examples of "virtual tug" satellite formations for forming large synthetic apertures in [[Low Earth Orbit]].
[[File:PLT-NS-Stationkeeping-Figure.jpg|thumb|Figure 10: PLT stationkeeping for north/south orbit maintenance for Peck's GEO spacecraft. Additionally illustrated is multi-vehicular orbit drag compensation with PLT by a resource vehicle on Low Earth Orbit.|380x380px]]
Similarly, small orbital craft that need to correct for orbital drag could do this with significantly less propellant, by moving a larger resource vehicle into a similar orbit with low inter-vehicle velocity.{{Citation needed|date=February 2016}} The replacement of such a resource vehicle could be faster and more economical.
=== Space travel === [[File:PLT-Mars-Specific-Energy-Graph.jpg|thumb|Figure 11: Specific energy as a function of spacecraft velocity relevant to Mars missions. The flight time to Mars is for flyby missions, and rendezvous missions would take more than twice longer. For 3 day flight to Mars, the photonic railway (PLT-BLP) would be several orders of magnitude energy efficient than the conventional rockets with Isp of 3,000.|405x405px]]Bae proposed a 4-staged developmental map towards interstellar flight.<ref name=":2" /> This would involve the photonic railway, a permanent energy-efficient transportation infrastructure based on Photonic Laser Thruster (PLT) in combination with Forward's model of beamed-laser propulsion (BLP),<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":3" /> a PLT-BLP hybrid.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /><ref name=":14"/><ref name=":17"/> This would reduce the cost and duration of interstellar commutes via proposed spacetrains.<ref name=":2" /> The Stage-1 focuses on the near-earth space endeavors, such as orbit tuning, with Photonic Laser Thruster. The Stage-2 focuses on Interlunar photonic railway between the earth and the moon. The Stage-3 focuses on Interplanetary photonic railway between the earth and planets, moons and asteroids in the solar system. The Stage-4 focuses on Interstellar photonic railway between the planets and moons of the solar system and those of other star systems.
==== Photonic railway<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/298090729_The_photonic_railway|title=The photonic railway|last=Bae|first=Young|date=2017|website=ResearchGate|publisher=Book Chapter 4 of New Frontiers in Space Propulsion, Nova Science Publisher|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-22}}</ref>==== If the photonic laser thruster is scalable for the use in such main space propulsion, multiple photonic laser thrusters can be used to construct a photonic railway that has been proposed as a potential permanent transport infrastructure for interplanetary or interstellar commutes, allowing the transport craft themselves to carry very little or no fuel.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S187538921202514X|title = Prospective of photon propulsion for interstellar flight|last = Bae|first = Y.K.|date = 2012|journal = Physics Procedia|accessdate = |doi = 10.1016/j.phpro.2012.08.026|pmid = |volume = 38|pages = 253–279|bibcode = 2012PhPro..38..253B}}</ref> The photonic railway<ref name=":2" /> was investigated for a space applications involving planets, moons and asteroids both in the solar system and other star systems, such as mining and setting up permanent habitation, with regular interplanetary and interstellar travel.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":3" />
For example, platforms could be built in Earth orbit and then used for constructing further platforms at one of the [[Lagrangian point|Lagrange points]] of a planet of interest.<ref name=":2" /> For Mars, solar power is still strong, thus solar pumped platforms could be operated near Mars. Planets farther from the sun might not support solar pumping, and the railway would involve two PLT-BLP systems near Earth.
Bae compared the energy need to speed spacecraft for conventional rockets and that for photonic railway or PLT-BLP, in terms of specific energy (J/kg) that is the energy required for propelling a unit mass to a given velocity.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":12" /> Fig. 11 shows examples of the specific energy (J/kg) as a function of the spacecraft velocity (km/s) related with the Mars photonic railway. Two curves represent the specific energies for conventional rockets with I<sub>sp</sub> = 500 s and 3,000 s, respectively. The upper straight solid line represents the specific energy for BLP and the lower straight solid line for photonic railway or PLT-BLP with M=1,000. Here M is the photon thrust amplification factor. It is interesting that BPL becomes more energy efficient than rockets with I<sub>sp</sub>=500 s, if the travel time needs to be shorter than 1 month. BPL becomes more energy efficient than rockets with I<sub>sp</sub>=3,000 s, if the travel time is shorter than a week. However, photonic railway or PLT-BPL with M=1,000 becomes more energy efficient than rockets with I<sub>sp</sub>=500 s, if the travel time needs to be shorter than 2 month. BPL becomes more energy efficient than rockets with I<sub>sp</sub>=3,000 s, if the travel time needs to be shorter than two weeks. Eventually, when the flight time needs to be 3 days, for example, both BLP and photonic railway or PLT-BLP are more energy efficient than rockets with I<sub>sp</sub>=3,000 s. This estimate demonstrates photonic railway is potentially the most energy efficient way to commute to planets in the solar system.
One interesting aspect of the Spacetrain on the photonic railway was realized that the continuous low level acceleration of up to 1 g will create an artificial gravity that may eliminate or minimize the health effects of [[weightlessness]] long term space travel in zero-gravity environment.<ref name=":2" /> This artificial gravity will play a crucial role in reducing or eliminating the health problems arising from the typical zero-g space travel environment.
A simple PLT system could provide continuous and constant thrust in a straight line. However, travel around the solar system involves interacting with planets and the sun, so trajectories and travel time calculations are more complex. Fu-Yuen Hsiao has investigated the trajectories of spacecraft relying entirely on a PLT.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Trajectory of spacecraft with photonic laser propulsion in the two-body problem|last = Hsiao|first = F.Y.|display-authors = etal|date = 2012|journal = Acta Astronautica|accessdate = |doi = 10.1016/j.actaastro.2012.11.006|pmid = |volume = 84|pages = 215–226|bibcode = 2013AcAau..84..215H}}</ref>
Bae's investigation concluded that the development of interplanetary and interstellar photonic railway will require development of the ways to utilize Photon [[Bose Einstein Condensation]] or diffraction-minimized laser beam propagation with non-diffracting beams, such as [[Bessel beam]], or [[x-ray lasers]] and future advanced material science and technologies. Bae further concluded that the realization of the interstellar photonic railway would require that the PLT technology developments ride on the [[Moore’s law]] as the 20th century silicon devices did.

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | logo = Piazza logo.png | logo_size = 215px | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | foundation = 2009 | location = [[Palo Alto, California|Palo Alto]], [[California|CA]] | key_people = [[Pooja Sankar]], CEO and Founder | industry = [[Education]], [[SaaS]] | homepage = http://www.piazza.com/ }}
'''Piazza''' is a Q&A web service. It can be described as "mixture between a [[wiki]] and a [[Internet forum|forum]]"<ref name="Kincaid, Jason">{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2010/02/05/piazzza-college-questions-answers/ |title=Piazzza Gives Classmates An Online Forum To Trade Their Knowledge |author=Kincaid, Jason |publisher=TechCrunch |date=5 February 2010 |accessdate=2 July 2011 }}</ref> that can be used with [[learning management systems]]. The word Piazza comes from the Italian word for plaza—a common city square where people can come together to share ideas and knowledge.<ref>https://piazza.com/stanford</ref>
==History== Pooja Sankar created the first prototype of Piazza in 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://research.csc.ncsu.edu/colloquia/seminar-post.php?id=403 |title=Piazzza - a new Q&A tool (free for academic purposes) |publisher=NCSU Dept. of Computer Science |date=20 April 2011 |work=Seminars & Colloquia in Computer Science |accessdate=2 July 2011 }} </ref><ref name="Rusli, Evelyn M">{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/04/technology/04piazza.html?pagewanted=1&ref=technology |title=Homework Help Site Has a Social Networking Twist |author=Rusli, Evelyn M. |publisher=The New York Times |date=3 July 2011 |accessdate=3 July 2011 }}</ref> By February 2010, Piazza was used by approximately 600 [[Stanford University|Stanford]] students.<ref name="Kincaid, Jason"/> In January 2011, Piazza opened to all institutions, reaching over 330 schools and tens of thousands of students by the summer of the same year.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://research.csc.ncsu.edu/colloquia/seminar-post.php?id=403 |title=Piazzza - a new Q&A tool (free for academic purposes) |publisher=NCSU Dept. of Computer Science |date=20 April 2011 |work=Seminars & Colloquia in Computer Science |accessdate=2 July 2011 }}</ref><ref name="Rusli, Evelyn M"/>
While the service originally operated under the name 'Piazzza',<ref>{{cite web|title=Wayback Machine - piazzza.com |url=https://www.piazzza.com/ |website=Internet Archive |accessdate=10 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110207123410/https://www.piazzza.com/ |archivedate=February 7, 2011 }}</ref> in June 2011, the third 'z' was dropped from Piazza's name.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://gigaom.com/2011/06/30/what-happens-when-students-create-their-own-collaboration-tools/ |title=What happens when students create their own collaboration tools? |author=Griffith, Terri |publisher=GigaOm |date=30 June 2011 |accessdate=13 March 2017 }}</ref>
===Funding=== * $8M announced on February 27, 2014 * $6M announced on January 6, 2012 * $1.5M announced on July 5, 2011
==Service== Users can publicly (and anonymously, if the head instructor allows it) ask questions, answer questions, and post notes. Each question prompts a collective answer to which any user can contribute and an instructor answer, shown directly below, which can only be edited by instructors. Multiple students are allowed contribute to each answer like the Wikipedia entries, and each answer have a version history that shows what each student wrote.<ref name=":0" /> Users are allowed to attach external files to posts, use [[LaTeX]] formatting, view a post's edit history, add follow-up questions, and receive email notifications when new content is added. The interface consists of a dynamic list of posts on the left side of the screen, a central panel for viewing and contributing to individual posts, and an upper bar for account control.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.piazza.com/help.html |title=Piazza Tutorial Class |publisher=Piazza Technologies, Inc. |year=2011 |accessdate=2 July 2011 }}</ref> According to the company's data, the average Piazza question is answered within 14 minutes.<ref name="Rusli, Evelyn M"/>
Individual Piazza classes are self-contained and can be locked with an access code. Anyone may create a class, but the head instructor retains full control over the class content, along with administrative abilities such as endorsing good answers and viewing more detailed statistics on class activity.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.piazza.com/help.html |title=Instructor FAQ Class |publisher=Piazza Technologies, Inc. |year=2011 |accessdate=2 July 2011 }}</ref>
The Piazza team is based in [[Palo Alto, California|Palo Alto]], [[California]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.piazza.com/privacy.html |title=Piazza Privacy Policy |publisher=Piazza Technologies, Inc. |date=29 May 2011 |accessdate=2 July 2011 }}</ref>
In November 2011, Piazza launched [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] [[mobile app]]s which would allow students share their ideas and get their queries answered.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/11/08/sequoia-backed-piazza-takes-qa-platform-for-students-mobile-with-ios-and-android-apps/|title=Sequoia-Backed Piazza Takes Q&A Platform For Students Mobile With iOS And Android Apps|last=Rao|first=Leena|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2017-10-09|language=en}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Social constructivism]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.piazza.com/ Official site] * [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/04/technology/04piazza.html?pagewanted=1&ref=technology/ Article in the New York Times] * [http://www.stanforddaily.com/2010/06/03/piazzza-the-homework-helper/ Article in the Stanford Daily] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130808131053/https://piazza.com/news.html List of News Articles] * [http://www.terrigriffith.com/blog/2010/02/04/piazzza-e20-classroom/ Featured post in Terri Griffith's Technology and Organizations blog]

DetonationV = | REFactor = }} |Section7={{Chembox Hazards | ExternalSDS = | EUClass = | MainHazards = | NFPA-H = | NFPA-F = | NFPA-R = | NFPA-S = | RPhrases = 2, 4, 23/24/25 | SPhrases = 28, 35, 37, 45 | RSPhrases = | FlashPtC = 187.5 | AutoignitionPtC = | ExploLimits = | LD50 = | PEL = }} |Section8={{Chembox Related | OtherAnions = | OtherCations = | OtherFunction = | OtherFunction_label = | OtherCompounds = }} }} '''Picramic acid''', also known as '''2-amino-4,6-dinitrophenol''',<ref>http://hazmap.nlm.nih.gov/category-details?id=3267&table=copytblagents</ref> is an [[acid]] obtained by neutralizing an alcoholic solution of [[picric acid]] with [[ammonium hydroxide]]. [[Hydrogen sulfide]] is then added to the resulting solution, which turns red, yielding sulfur and red crystals. These are the ammonium salts of picramic acid, from which it can be extracted using [[acetic acid]].<ref>http://www.jbc.org/content/35/3/565.full.pdf</ref>
Picramic acid is [[explosive]] and very [[toxic]]. It has a [[Bitterness (taste)|bitter]] taste.<ref>http://chemicalland21.com/specialtychem/perchem/PICRAMIC%20ACID.htm</ref>

[[File:Prefabricated house construction.gif|thumb|right|Construction of a prefabricated modular house ([[:File:Prefabricated house construction.ogg|Click here for a time-lapse video]])]] A '''prefabricated building''', informally a '''prefab''', is a building that is manufactured and constructed using [[prefabrication]]. It consists of factory-made components or units that are transported and assembled on-site to form the complete building.
==History== [[File:Villa Undine.JPG|thumb|''Villa Undine'' in [[Binz]] on German [[Rügen|Rugia Island]], built in 1885 by ''Wolgaster Holzbau''.]] [[File:Prefabfront.jpg|thumb|right|Prefabricated post-war home at [[Chiltern Open Air Museum]] - Universal House, Mark 3, steel frame clad with corrugated [[asbestos cement]]]] [[File:prefab 20060625.jpg|thumb|right|A 1950s metal UK prefab at the [[Rural Life Centre, Tilford]], Surrey.]]
Buildings have been built in one place and reassembled in another throughout history. This was especially true for mobile activities, or for new settlements; [[Great House (Cape Ann)|one of the first buildings]] at [[Cape Ann]] in 1624 was probably partially prefabricated, and was rapidly disassembled and moved at least once. [[John Rollo]] described in 1801 earlier use of portable hospital buildings in the [[West Indies]]<ref name="Rollo">{{cite book|last1=Rollo|first1=John|title=A short account of the Royal Artillery Hospital at Woolwich: with some observations on the management of artillery soldiers, respecting the preservation of health.|date=1801|publisher=Mawman|location=London|pages=32–33}}</ref> Possibly the first advertised prefab house was the "Manning cottage". A London carpenter, Henry Manning, constructed a house that was built in components, then shipped and assembled by British emigrants. This was published at the time (advertisement, South Australian Record, 1837) and a few still stand in Australia.<ref>[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=94119708 Prefab: From Utilitarian Home To Design Icon], by Jim Zarroli, Morning Edition, September 15, 2008, NPR</ref> One such is the [[Friends Meeting House, Adelaide]].<ref>[http://www.postcards-sa.com.au/features2009/quakers_meeting_house.html Channel 9 South Australia Pty Ltd > Postcards > Friend's Meeting House] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120317183329/http://www.postcards-sa.com.au/features2009/quakers_meeting_house.html |date=2012-03-17 }} Retrieved 8 September 2011 </ref><ref>[http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/resources/parks/CoolamineSection3.pdf This reference has a contemporary sketch and recent photograph of the Friends' Meeting House]</ref> [[File:Friends Meeting House, Adelaide.JPG|right|thumb|Friends Meeting House, North Adelaide, still in service.]] The peak year for the importation of portable buildings to Australia was 1853, when several hundred arrived. These have been identified as coming from [[Liverpool]], [[Boston]] and [[Singapore]] (with Chinese instructions for re-assembly).<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Lewis | first1 = Miles | year = 1985 | title = The Diagnosis of Prefabricated Buildings | journal = Australian Historical Archaeology | volume = 3 | pages = 58–68 | accessdate = 2017-07-30 | url = http://ashadocs.org/aha/03/03_04_Lewis.pdf }}</ref> In [[Barbados]] the [[Chattel house]] was a form of prefabricated building which was developed by emancipated slaves who had limited rights to build upon land they did not own. As the buildings were moveable they were legally regarded as [[Personal property|chattel]]s.<ref>{{cite book | last =Ali | first = Arif | authorlink = | title = Barbados: Just Beyond Your Imagination | publisher = [[Hansib]] | series = Hansib Caribbean | year = 1996 | doi = | isbn = 1-870518-54-3 }}</ref>
In 1855 during the [[Crimean War]], after [[Florence Nightingale]] wrote a letter to ''[[The Times]]'', [[Isambard Kingdom Brunel]] was commissioned to design a prefabricated modular hospital. In five months he designed the [[Renkioi Hospital]]: a 1,000 patient hospital, with innovations in sanitation, ventilation and a flushing toilet.<ref>Renkioi: Brunel's Forgotten Crimean War Hospital by Christopher Silver</ref> Fabricator [[William Eassie]] constructed the required 16 units in [[Gloucester Docks]], shipped directly to the [[Dardanelles]]. Only used from March 1856 to September 1857, it reduced the death rate from 42% to 3.5%.
The world's first prefabricated, pre-cast panelled apartment blocks were pioneered in [[Liverpool]]. A process was invented by city engineer [[John Alexander Brodie]], whose inventive genius also had him inventing the football goal net. The tram stables at Walton in [[Liverpool]] followed in 1906. The idea was not extensively adopted in Britain, however was widely adopted elsewhere, particularly in Eastern Europe.
Prefabricated homes were produced during the [[Gold Rush]] in the United States, when kits were produced to enable Californian prospectors to quickly construct accommodation. Homes were available in kit form by mail order in the United States in 1908.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chetboddy.com/Pages/factorybuilt.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-08-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060902005129/http://www.chetboddy.com/Pages/factorybuilt.html |archivedate=2006-09-02 |df= }}</ref>
Prefabricated housing was popular during the [[World War II|Second World War]] due to the need for mass accommodation for military personnel. The United States used [[Quonset hut]]s as military buildings, and in the United Kingdom prefabricated buildings used included [[Nissen hut]]s and [[Bellman Hangar]]s. 'Prefabs' were built after the war as a means of quickly and cheaply providing quality housing as a replacement for the housing destroyed during [[the Blitz]]. The proliferation of prefabricated housing across the country was a result of the [[Burt Committee]] and the [[Housing (Temporary Accommodation) Act 1944]]. Under the [[Ministry of Works (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Works]] [[Emergency Factory Made]] housing programme, a specification was drawn up and bid on by various private construction and manufacturing companies. After approval by the MoW, companies could bid on Council led development schemes, resulting in whole estates of prefabs constructed to provide accommodation for those made homeless by the War and ongoing [[slum clearance]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.localhistory.scit.wlv.ac.uk/interesting/prefabs/prefabs.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-08-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061008181601/http://www.localhistory.scit.wlv.ac.uk/interesting/prefabs/prefabs.htm |archivedate=2006-10-08 |df= }}</ref> Almost 160,000 had been built in the UK by 1948 at a cost of close to £216 million. The largest single prefab estate in Britain<ref>[[Belle Vale, Liverpool]]</ref> was at [[Belle Vale]] (South Liverpool), where more than 1,100 were built after World War 2. The estate was demolished in the 1960s amid much controversy as the prefabs were very popular with residents at the time. [[File:Prefabfrontroom.jpg|thumb|Amersham Prefab (COAM)-front room showing solid-fuel fire]] Prefabs were aimed at families, and typically had an entrance hall, two bedrooms (parents and children), a bathroom (a room with a bath)  — which was a novel innovation for many Britons at that time, a separate toilet, a living room and an equipped (not ''fitted'' in the modern sense) kitchen. Construction materials included steel, aluminium, timber or [[asbestos]], depending on the type of dwelling. The aluminium ''Type B2'' prefab was produced as four pre-assembled sections which could be transported by lorry anywhere in the country.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.walespast.com/article-print.shtml?id=73 |title=Archived copy |access-date=2006-08-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060518065604/http://www.walespast.com/article-print.shtml?id=73 |archive-date=2006-05-18 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> [[File:Prefabkitchen.jpg|thumb|left|Amersham Prefab's Kitchen (COAM)-showing Belling cooker, Ascot wash heater and fridge]] The Universal House (pictured left & lounge diner right) was given to the [[Chiltern Open Air Museum]] after 40 years temporary use. The Mark 3 was manufactured by the Universal Housing Company Ltd, Rickmansworth.
The United States used prefabricated housing for troops during the war and for GIs returning home. ''Prefab'' classrooms were popular with UK schools increasing their rolls during the [[baby boom]] of the 1950s and 1960s.
Many buildings were designed with a five-ten year life span, but have far exceeded this, with a number surviving today. In 2002, for example, the city of [[Bristol]] still had residents living in 700 examples.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/property/main.jhtml?xml=/property/2002/03/23/prefab23.xml | work=The Daily Telegraph | location=London | title=The prefab four | first=Lesley | last=Gillilan | date=March 23, 2002 | accessdate=May 22, 2010}}</ref> Many UK councils have been in the process of demolishing the last surviving examples of Second World War prefabs in order to comply with the British government's [[Decent Homes Standard]], which came into effect in 2010. There has, however, been a recent revival in prefabricated methods of construction in order to compensate for the United Kingdom's current housing shortage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/mortgages/article.html?in_article_id=407133&in_page_id=8|title=New age of the prefab house|work=This is Money}}</ref>
==Prefabs and the modernist movement== Architects are incorporating modern designs into the prefabricated houses of today. Prefab housing should no longer be compared to a mobile home in terms of appearance, but to that of a complex modernist design.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.transportablehomefinance.com.au/transportableHomeExplained.html|title=Transportable Homes, Explained|publisher=Transportable home finance|accessdate=2008-11-26}}</ref> There has also been an increase in the use of "green" materials in the construction of these prefab houses. Consumers can easily select between different environmentally friendly finishes and wall systems. Since these homes are built in parts, it is easy for a home owner to add additional rooms or even solar panels to the roofs. Many prefab houses can be customized to the client's specific location and climate, making prefab homes much more flexible and modern than before.
There is a [[zeitgeist]] in architectural circles and the spirit of the age favors the small carbon footprint of "prefab." Eminent amongst the new breed of off the shelf luxury modernist products is the perrinepod,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inhabitat.com/2007/08/10/prefab-friday-perrinepod/|title=PREFAB FRIDAY: Perrinepod|work=inhabitat.com}}</ref> which has found favor worldwide for its green credentials and three-day build time.
==In communist countries== {{main|Urban planning in communist countries}}
[[File:Plattenbauten 02 Lobeda West-2011.jpg|right|thumb]] Many eastern European countries had suffered physical damage during [[World War Two]] and their economies were in a very poor state. There was a need to reconstruct cities which had been severely damaged due to the war. For example, [[Warsaw]], [[Poland]] had been practically razed to the ground under the planned destruction of Warsaw by German forces after the 1944 [[Warsaw Uprising]]. The centre of [[Dresden]], Germany had been totally destroyed by the 1945 Allied bombardment. Stalingrad had been largely destroyed and only a small number of structures were left standing.
Prefabricated buildings served as an inexpensive and quick way to alleviate the massive housing shortages associated with the wartime destruction and large-scale [[urbanization]] and [[rural flight]].
==Prefabricated commercial buildings== [[File:Zubří, Tesco (01).jpg|thumb|right|[[Tesco]] modular store in [[Zubří (Vsetín District)|Zubří]], [[Czech Republic]]]] [[Broad Sustainable Building]]s of Changsha, China has been continuously breaking records on building skyscrapers in record times which went viral in YouTube.<ref>{{Citation|last=Sami|title=Z15 Weihai: BSB builds 17 Stories in 2 days|date=2014-07-09|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IDcpOavoOrM&list=PLiwZ62tpFvnh4eNmGUVCFO4uj_hZJON3b&index=10|accessdate=2017-12-23}}</ref> Now they aim to build [[Sky City (Changsha)|Sky City]], a [[Megatall|mega tall]] skyscraper in record time.<ref>{{Citation|last=CTBUH|title=CTBUH 2013 London Conference - Closing Plenary: The Future of Tall? Q&A|date=2013-10-17|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_vOrsvg1kXQ&index=1&list=PL1ED688B8056A2E9A&t=827s|accessdate=2017-12-23}}</ref>
[[McDonald's]] uses prefabricated structures for their buildings, and set a record of constructing a building and opening for business within 13 hours (on pre-prepared ground works).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://projects.bre.co.uk/prefabrication/prefabrication.pdf |title=Data |website=projects.bre.co.uk |format=PDF}}</ref>
In the UK, the major supermarkets have each developed a modular unit system to shop building, based on the systems developed by German cost retailler [[Aldi]] and the Danish supermarket chain [[Netto (store)|Netto]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Prefabricated Supermarket Buildings|url=http://www.hts-ind.co.uk/blog-uk/prefabricated-supermarket-buildings/|publisher=www.hts-ind.co.uk|date=7 February 2017}}</ref>

[[File:PureCell System 400 CEP.jpg|thumb|Doosan Fuel Cell 400kW fuel cell]]
The '''PureCell System''' is a stationary [[phosphoric acid fuel cell]] designed, manufactured and marketed by [[Doosan Fuel Cell America]] (formerly [[ClearEdge Power]]/[[UTC Power]]) of [[South Windsor, Connecticut]]. Intended for [[distributed generation]] and [[micro combined heat and power]] applications, it is considered a good match for commercial and industrial buildings such as hotels, hospitals, data centers, supermarkets and educational institutions.<ref name="Benefits">{{cite web|url=http://www.utcpower.com/knowledge-library/benefits |accessdate=January 20, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111220120640/http://www.utcpower.com/knowledge-library/benefits |archivedate=December 20, 2011 }}</ref> PureCell System says that its users will see lower energy costs,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beckerandbecker.com/documents/Powering-Up-With-New-Fuel-Cells-WSJ.com.pdf |title=Powering Up With New Fuel Cells |author=Craig Karmin |publisher=Beckerandbecker.com |accessdate=2013-10-31}}</ref> reduced emissions, 95% system efficiency, 10-year cell stack durability<ref>{{cite web|last=Clancy |first=Heather |url=http://www.smartplanet.com/blog/business-brains/energy-in-a-box-more-businesses-try-prime-fuel-cells/17585 |title=Energy-in-a-box: More businesses try prime fuel cells |publisher=SmartPlanet |date=2011-07-27 |accessdate=2013-10-31}}</ref> and 20-year product life.<ref name="busweek">{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=8142377 |title=UTC Power, LLC: Private Company Information - Businessweek |publisher=Investing.businessweek.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-31}}</ref> It utilizes a combustion-free process with natural gas and converts heat exhaust into cooling and heating, turning potential waste into usable energy.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2009/09/14/idUS122215+14-Sep-2009+PRN20090914 |title=UTC Power Says Supermarkets a Good Fit for Fuel Cells |publisher=Reuters |date=2009-09-14 |accessdate=2013-10-31}}</ref>
==Installations== On August 17, 2011, it was announced that the PureCell Model 400 system fleet had reached 200,000 hours of field operation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fuelcellsworks.com/news/2011/08/17/governor-dannel-p-malloy-visits-utc-power-as-company-celebrates-milestone/ |title=Governor Dannel P. Malloy Visits UTC Power as Company Celebrates Milestone |publisher=FuelCellsWorks |date=2011-08-17 |accessdate=2012-07-17}}</ref> In September 2013, [[ClearEdge Power]] announced that its 400 kW stationary fuel cell surpassed 1,000,000 hours of field operation.<ref>http://www.worldofcogeneration.com/cogeneration_chp/3418-clearedge_power_purecell_fuel_cell_fleet_surpasses_one_million_h.html</ref>
[[ClearEdge Power|ClearEdge Power’s]] chief operating officer Joe Triompo<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.remindernews.com/article/2013/02/14/clearedge-power-closes-deal-on-utc-power |title=ClearEdge Power closes deal on UTC Power |publisher=Reminder News |date= |accessdate=2013-10-31}}</ref> said that PureCell System repeat customers include [[The Coca-Cola Company]], [[Cox Communications]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/cox-communications-partners-with-utc-power-to-install-fuel-cells-in-california-115494739.html |title=Cox Communications Partners with UTC Power to Install Fuel Cells in California - SOUTH WINDSOR, Conn., Feb. 7, 2011/PRNewswire/ |location=Connecticut, California |publisher=Prnewswire.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-17}}</ref> and [[Whole Foods Market]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sustainablebusiness.com/index.cfm/go/news.display/id/22665 |title=Fuel Cell Industry Growing Again |publisher=Sustainablebusiness.com |date=2011-07-13 |accessdate=2012-07-17}}</ref>
Other customers include [[First National Bank of Omaha]],<ref>http://www.energymanagertoday.com/first-national-bank-of-omaha-upgrades-its-fuel-cell-system-097121/</ref> [[Price Chopper Supermarkets]],<ref name="pricechopper">{{cite web|url=http://www.environmentalleader.com/2010/01/29/price-chopper-uses-fuel-cell-power/ |title=Price Chopper Uses Fuel Cell Power · Environmental Management & Energy News · Environmental Leader |publisher=Environmentalleader.com |date=2010-01-29 |accessdate=2012-07-17}}</ref> the [[Condé Nast Building]] (officially, 4 Times Square), [[Shaw's and Star Market|Shaw's]],<ref name="masstech">{{cite web|url=http://www.masstech.org/project_detail.cfm?ProjSeq=1153 |accessdate=February 9, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100615142054/http://masstech.org/project_detail.cfm?ProjSeq=1153 |archivedate=June 15, 2010 }}</ref> [[GS Group|GS Power Co.]]/[[Samsung]],<ref name="samsung">{{cite web|url=http://www.renewableenergyworld.com/rea/news/article/2008/10/samsung-everland-to-install-4-8-mw-fuel-cell-system-53975 |title=Samsung Everland To Install 4.8-MW Fuel Cell System | Renewable Energy News Article |publisher=Renewableenergyworld.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-17}}</ref> Becker + Becker,<ref name="statestreet">{{cite web|author=Thomas MacMillan |url=http://www.newhavenindependent.org/index.php/archives/entry/360_states_green_generator_stymied/ |title=360 State's Green Power Goes Untapped |publisher=New Haven Independent |date=2011-08-26 |accessdate=2012-07-17}}</ref> [[St. Helena Hospital]], the [[World Trade Center (2001–present)|World Trade Center]],<ref name="tradecenter">{{cite web|url=http://www.renewableenergyworld.com/rea/news/article/2008/07/fuel-cells-to-power-new-world-trade-center-52993 |title=Fuel Cells To Power New World Trade Center | Renewable Energy News Article |publisher=Renewableenergyworld.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-17}}</ref> [[The Octagon (Roosevelt Island, New York)|The Octagon]],<ref name="nyapt">{{cite web|author=Susan DeFreitas |url=http://www.earthtechling.com/2011/06/fuel-cell-powering-new-york-apartments/ |title=Fuel Cell Powering New York Apartments |publisher=Earthtechling |date=2011-06-08 |accessdate=2012-07-17}}</ref> [[New Haven City Hall and County Courthouse|New Haven City Hall]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Appel |first=Allan |url=http://www.newhavenindependent.org/index.php/archives/entry/fuel_cell_drop_successful/id_43587 |title=1st Fuel Cell Arrives At City Hall |publisher=New Haven Independent |date=2012-01-16 |accessdate=2012-07-17}}</ref> [[South Windsor High School]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ctcleanenergy.com/YourBusinessorInstitution/CommercialInstallations/SchoolsandEducationalFacilities/SouthWindsorHighSchool/tabid/445/Default.aspx |title=South Windsor High School |publisher=Ctcleanenergy.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-17}}</ref> [[360 State Street]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beckerandbecker.com/documents/biz-new-haven-2011-feb.pdf |title=Business New Haven |publisher=Beckerandbecker.com |accessdate=2013-10-31}}</ref> [[Albertsons (SuperValu)|Albertsons]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://supermarketnews.com/latest-news/albertsons-store-use-fuel-cell-energy |title=Albertsons Store to Use Fuel Cell for Energy | Latest News content from |publisher=Supermarket News |date=2010-08-31 |accessdate=2012-07-17}}</ref> the [[University of Connecticut]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.energy.uconn.edu/ |title=Center for Clean Energy Engineering Web |publisher=Energy.uconn.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-07-17}}</ref> [[Diversey, Inc.]],<ref>{{cite web|author=MICHAEL BURKE mburke@journaltimes.com |url=http://www.journaltimes.com/news/local/article_48050e18-0c53-11e0-90a7-001cc4c002e0.html |title=$2.5M fuel cell to heat, power Diversey HQ |publisher=Journaltimes.com |date=2010-12-20 |accessdate=2012-07-17}}</ref> and [[Eastern Connecticut State University]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Bachman |first=Dwight |url=http://www.easternct.edu/mt-static/press_releases/2011/10/eastern-works-with-utcp-on-campus-fuel-cell-project.html |title=Eastern Works with UTCP on Campus Fuel Cell Project - Press Releases |publisher=Easternct.edu |date=2011-10-31 |accessdate=2012-07-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120524171633/http://www.easternct.edu/mt-static/press_releases/2011/10/eastern-works-with-utcp-on-campus-fuel-cell-project.html |archivedate=2012-05-24 |df= }}</ref>

{{about|radiators in automobiles, buildings, and electronics||Radiator (disambiguation)}} {{More citations needed|date=March 2009}} [[File:Automobile radiator.jpg|thumb|right|Water-air convective cooling radiator]] '''Radiators''' are [[heat exchanger]]s used to transfer [[thermal energy]] from one medium to another for the purpose of cooling and heating. The majority of radiators are constructed to function in [[automobiles]], [[buildings]], and [[electronics]]. The radiator is always a source of heat to its environment, although this may be for either the purpose of [[#Heating|heating]] this environment, or for cooling the fluid or [[coolant]] supplied to it, as for [[#Engine cooling|engine cooling]]. Despite the name, most radiators transfer the bulk of their heat via [[convection]] instead of [[thermal radiation]].
The Roman [[hypocaust]] is an early example of a type of radiator for building space heating. [[Franz San Galli]], a Prussian-born [[Russia]]n businessman living in [[St. Petersburg]], is credited with inventing the heating radiator around 1855,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gruner-fam.de/SanGalli-E.html |title=Family Sangalli / San Galli |publisher=Gruner-fam.de |accessdate=2011-09-20 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100207113505/http://www.votgk.com/press/energyhistory/sangalli/ |archivedate=2010-02-07 |dead-url=y |url=http://www.votgk.com/press/energyhistory/sangalli/ |title=The hot boxes of San Galli |language=ru }}</ref> having received a radiator patent in 1857,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saint-petersburg.com/german/franz-san-galli/|title=Franz San-Galli, German industrialist in St. Petersburg, Russia|website=www.saint-petersburg.com}}</ref> but American Joseph Nason developed a primitive radiator in 1841<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://www.heatinghelp.com/files/articles/1257/234.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-08-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826115728/http://www.heatinghelp.com/files/articles/1257/234.pdf |archivedate=26 August 2014 |df=dmy }}</ref> and received a number of U.S. patents for hot water and steam heating.<ref name="auto"/>
==Radiation and convection== [[Heat transfer]] from a radiator occurs by all the usual mechanisms: [[thermal radiation]], [[convection]] into flowing air or liquid, and conduction into the air or liquid. A radiator may even transfer heat by [[Phase transition|phase change]], for example, drying a pair of socks. In practice, the term "radiator" refers to any of a number of devices in which a liquid circulates through exposed pipes (often with fins or other means of increasing surface area). The term "convector" refers to a class of devices in which the source of heat is not directly exposed.
To increase the surface area available for heat exchange with the surroundings, a radiator will have multiple fins, in contact with the tube carrying liquid pumped through the radiator. Air (or other exterior fluid) in contact with the fins carries off heat. If air flow is obstructed by dirt or damage to the fins, that portion of the radiator is ineffective at heat transfer.
==Heating== [[File:Radiator.svg|thumb|A Type 22 Convector Radiator, typical of a standard central heating system|alt=Type 21 Convector Radiator]] {{Main|Radiator (heating)}} Radiators are commonly used to heat buildings. In a [[central heating system]], hot water or sometimes steam is generated in a central boiler and circulated by pumps through radiators within the building, where this heat is transferred to the surroundings.
==Engine cooling== [[File:Radiateur de voiture - 2.jpg|thumb|right|Car engine bay, with radiator in front]] {{Main|Radiator (engine cooling)}} [[File:Radiatore.jpg|thumb|Auto radiators with a double grid of tubes: staggered grids on the left, parallel grids on the right]] Radiators are used for cooling [[internal combustion engine]]s, mainly in automobiles but also in piston-engined aircraft, [[railway locomotive]]s, [[motorcycle]]s, [[Fossil-fuel power plant|stationary generating plant]]s and other places where such engines are used.
To cool down the engine, a [[coolant]] is passed through the [[engine block]], where it absorbs heat from the engine. The hot coolant is then fed into the inlet tank of the radiator (located either on the top of the radiator, or along one side), from which it is distributed across the radiator core through tubes to another tank on the opposite end of the radiator. As the coolant passes through the radiator tubes on its way to the opposite tank, it transfers much of its heat to the tubes which, in turn, transfer the heat to the [[Fin (extended surface)|fins]] that are lodged between each row of tubes. The fins then release the heat to the ambient air. Fins are used to greatly increase the contact surface of the tubes to the air, thus increasing the exchange efficiency. The cooled coolant is fed back to the engine, and the cycle repeats. Normally, the radiator does not reduce the temperature of the coolant back to ambient air temperature, but it is still sufficiently cooled to keep the engine from overheating.
This coolant is usually water-based, with the addition of [[glycol]]s to prevent freezing and other additives to limit [[corrosion]], [[erosion]] and [[cavitation]]. However, the coolant may also be an oil. The first engines used [[thermosiphon]]s to circulate the coolant; today, however, all but the smallest engines use [[pump]]s.
Up to the 1980s, radiator cores were often made of [[copper]] (for fins) and [[brass]] (for tubes, headers, and side-plates, while tanks could also be made of [[brass]] or of [[plastic]], often a [[polyamide]]). Starting in the 1970s, use of [[aluminium]] increased, eventually taking over the vast majority of vehicular radiator applications. The main inducements for aluminium are reduced weight and cost.
Since air has a lower [[heat capacity]] and [[density]] than liquid coolants, a fairly large [[volume flow rate]] (relative to the coolant's) must be blown through the radiator core to capture the heat from the coolant. Radiators often have one or more [[Mechanical fan|fan]]s that blow air through the radiator. To save fan power consumption in vehicles, radiators are often behind the grille at the front end of a vehicle. [[Short ram air intake|Ram air]] can give a portion or all of the necessary cooling air flow when the coolant temperature remains below the system's designed maximum temperature, and the fan remains disengaged.
==Electronics== {{main|Heat sink}} [[File:Harumphy.dg965.heatsink.jpg|thumb|A passive heatsink on a motherboard]] As electronic devices become smaller, the problem of dispersing [[waste heat]] becomes more difficult. Tiny radiators known as [[heat sink]]s are used to convey heat from the electronic components into a cooling air stream. Heatsink do not use water, rather they conduct the heat from the source (high-performance heat sinks have copper to conduct better). Heat is transferred to the air by conduction and convection; a relatively small proportion of heat is transferred by radiation owing to the low temperature of semiconductor devices compared to their surroundings.
==Spacecraft== {{see also|Spacecraft thermal control}} Radiators are found as components of some spacecraft. These radiators work by radiating heat energy away as light (generally infrared given the temperatures at which spacecraft try to operate) because in the vacuum of space neither convection nor conduction can work to transfer heat away. On the International Space Station, these can be seen clearly as large white panels attached to the main truss. They can be found on both manned and unmanned craft.<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/structure/elements/radiators.html#.VgcSEMtVhBc | title = Radiators | work = International Space Station | publisher = [[NASA]] | accessdate = September 26, 2015 }}</ref>
